en.purpose: To evaluate trunk stability and mobility in patients with neurological deficits.
en.use:
The Trunk Impairment Scale score is calculated based on evaluation of 3 areas: static balance, dynamic balance and coordination. Each of these 3 areas are evaluated based on certain components. The total score ranges from 0-23. Healthy individuals should achieve a perfect score of 23. The scores for the 3 areas range as follows:

Static balance: 0 - 7; evaluated with 3 components

Dynamic balance: 0 - 10; evaluated with 10 components

Coordination: 0 - 6; evaluated with 4 components

The Trunk Impairment Scale has been shown to exhibit sufficient reliability, internal consistency and validity for use in clinical practice and research. It is mainly used to assess and quantify the trunk stability and mobility in patients who may have certain neurological deficits.
en.misuse: The TIS score mainly evaluates the sitting balance and coordination of patients. It should not be used to draw insights about the patient's standing or movement balance.

other_details.en: Trunk impairment scale calculation helps to assess the balance and coordination of patients.
other_details.references: Verheyden, G, Mertin, J, Preger, et al.  (2004). The Trunk Impairment Scale: A new tool to measure motor impairment of the trunk after stroke. Clinical Rehabilitation, 18, 326–334.
